hints_html:
What is the dimension of the least square solution vector x?

The equation Ax = b is overdetermined, and does not have a solution. What we mean by least square solution x is the vector \(\hat{\mathbf x}\) that satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} \|A\hat{\mathbf x} - \mathbf b\|^2 = \text{min}_{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^2} \|A \mathbf x - \mathbf b\|^2\end{aligned}\]

In order to find the least square solution \(\hat{\mathbf x}\) solve the normal equations

\[\begin{aligned} A^TA \hat{\mathbf x} = A^T \mathbf b\end{aligned}\]

Now that you know \(\hat{\mathbf x}\) it is time to look at how the matrix A and the vector b were chosen. How does this relate to the equation of a line

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = mx + t\end{aligned}\]

Consider each of the four points, one at a time.
hints_latex:
What is the dimension of the least square solution vector
\textbf{\emph{x}}?

Now that you know $\hat{\mathbf x}$ it is time to look at how the matrix
\emph{A} and the vector \textbf{\emph{b}} were chosen. How does this
relate to the equation of a line

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
y = mx + t
\end{align*} Consider each of the four points, one at a time.
hints_raw:
What is the dimension of the least square solution vector '''''x'''''?
The equation ''A'''x''' = '''b''''' is overdetermined, and does not have a solution. What we mean by ''least square solution '''x''''' is the vector <math>\hat{\mathbf x}</math> that satisfies
:<math>
\|A\hat{\mathbf x} - \mathbf b\|^2 = \text{min}_{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^2} \|A \mathbf x - \mathbf b\|^2
</math>
In order to find the least square solution <math> \hat{\mathbf x} </math> solve the '''normal equations'''
:<math>
A^TA \hat{\mathbf x} = A^T \mathbf b
</math>
Now that you know <math> \hat{\mathbf x} </math> it is time to look at how the matrix ''A'' and the vector '''''b''''' were chosen. How does this relate to the equation of a line
:<math> \displaystyle
y = mx + t
</math>
Consider each of the four points, one at a time.
sols_html:
The least squares solution vector \(\hat{\mathbf x}\) is a 2x1 vector. We can quickly find it using the normal equations.

\[\begin{aligned} A^T A \hat{\mathbf x} &= A^T \mathbf b \\ \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \hat{\mathbf x} &= \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \mathbf b \\ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 4 & 2 \\ 2 & 6 \end{array}\right] \hat{\mathbf x} &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 5 \\ 6 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

To find \(\hat{\mathbf x}\) from here we can either invert the matrix on the left hand side, or use gaussian elimination. We choose the latter.

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 4 & 2 & 5 \\ 2 & 6 & 6 \end{array}\right] \rightarrow \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 4 & 2 & 5 \end{array}\right] \rightarrow \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & -10 & -7 \end{array}\right] \rightarrow \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 9/10 \\ 0 & 1 & 7/10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \hat{\mathbf x} = \left[\begin{array}{c} 9/10 \\ 7/10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Finally, how does this translate to the linear function whose graph best fits the four given points? In other words, find m and t such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = mx + t\end{aligned}\]

best fits the four given points (x1,y1), (x2,y2), (x3,y3), (x4,y4). To answer this we need to understand how the matrix A and the vector b were chosen. We notice that b holds the y values. Further, the x values of the points, are in the second column of A. The first column of A is ones and this is because the same constant t appears for each (x,y) pair. In matrix notation

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & x_1 \\ 1 & x_2 \\ 1 & x_3 \\ 1 & x_4 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} \hat{\mathbf x}_1 \\ \hat{\mathbf x}_2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ y_3 \\ y_4 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Reading \(\mathbf b = A \hat{\mathbf x}\) line by line reveals

\[\begin{aligned} y_j = 1 \hat{\mathbf x}_1 + x_j \hat{\mathbf x}_2 = \hat{\mathbf x}_2 x_j + \hat{\mathbf x}_1 = 7/10 x_j + 9/10\end{aligned}\]

for j = 1,2,3,4. Comparing to y = mx + t we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} m = 7/10, \quad t = 9/10\end{aligned}\]

The graph below is just for illustration purposes. It is not necessary to include a graph in your answer.

Therefore, the linear function is given by

\[\begin{aligned} y = \frac7{10} x + \frac9{10}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The least squares solution vector <math> \hat{\mathbf x} </math> is a 2x1 vector. We can quickly find it using the normal equations.

:<math> \begin{align}
A^T A \hat{\mathbf x} &= A^T \mathbf b \\
\left[\begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\
-1 & 0 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2
\end{array}\right] \hat{\mathbf x} &= \left[\begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\
-1 & 0 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right] \mathbf b \\
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
4 & 2 \\ 2 & 6
\end{array}\right] \hat{\mathbf x} &= \left[\begin{array}{c}
5 \\ 6
\end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>

To find <math> \hat{\mathbf x} </math> from here we can either invert the matrix on the left hand side, or use gaussian elimination. We choose the latter.
:<math> \begin{align}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
4 & 2 & 5 \\ 2 & 6 & 6
\end{array}\right] \rightarrow 
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 3 & 3 \\ 4 & 2 & 5
\end{array}\right] \rightarrow 
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & -10 & -7
\end{array}\right] \rightarrow 
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 0 & 9/10 \\ 0 & 1 & 7/10
\end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>

Hence
:<math>
\hat{\mathbf x} = \left[\begin{array}{c} 9/10 \\ 7/10 \end{array}\right]
</math>


Finally, how does this translate to the linear function whose graph best fits the four given points? In other words, find ''m'' and ''t'' such that
:<math> \displaystyle
y = mx + t
</math>
best fits the four given points (''x''<sub>1</sub>,''y''<sub>1</sub>), (''x''<sub>2</sub>,''y''<sub>2</sub>), (''x''<sub>3</sub>,''y''<sub>3</sub>), (''x''<sub>4</sub>,''y''<sub>4</sub>). To answer this we need to understand how the matrix ''A'' and the vector '''''b''''' were chosen. We notice that '''''b''''' holds the ''y'' values. Further, the ''x'' values of the points, are in the second column of ''A''.  The first column of ''A'' is ones and this is because the same constant '''''t''''' appears for each (x,y) pair.  In matrix notation
:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & x_1 \\ 1 & x_2 \\ 1 & x_3 \\ 1 & x_4
\end{array}\right]
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\hat{\mathbf x}_1 \\ \hat{\mathbf x}_2
\end{array}\right] =
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
y_1 \\ y_2 \\ y_3 \\ y_4
\end{array}\right]
</math>

Reading <math> \mathbf b = A \hat{\mathbf x} </math> line by line reveals
:<math>
y_j = 1 \hat{\mathbf x}_1 + x_j \hat{\mathbf x}_2 = \hat{\mathbf x}_2 x_j + \hat{\mathbf x}_1 = 7/10 x_j + 9/10
</math>
for ''j = 1,2,3,4''. Comparing to ''y = mx + t'' we obtain
:<math>
m = 7/10, \quad t = 9/10
</math>

''The graph below is just for illustration purposes. It is not necessary to include a graph in your answer.''
[[File:Fig 221 April 2013 11.png|400px]]

Therefore, the linear function is given by
:<math>
y = \frac7{10} x + \frac9{10}
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the follow matrix A and vector b:

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \quad \mathbf{b} = \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Find the least squares solution x for the linear system Ax = b. Use this to find a linear function whose graph best fits the points (-1,0), (0,1), (1,2), and (2,2) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\).
statement_raw:
Consider the follow matrix ''A'' and vector '''b''':

:<math>
A = \left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2
\end{array}\right] \quad \mathbf{b} = \left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\ 1 \\ 2 \\ 2
\end{array}\right]
</math>

Find the least squares solution '''x''' for the linear system ''A'''x''' = '''b'''''. Use this to find a linear function whose graph best fits the points ''(-1,0)'', ''(0,1)'', ''(1,2)'', and ''(2,2)'' in <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>.
